item.title: Self-supervised Learning: Theories (Part 2)
item.description:
2021-09-11T14:30:00 -2021-09-11T16:00:00
We will dive deep into Section 6 of the paper arXiv:2006.08218. Here are a few topics to be explored. InfoGAN objective; Positive and negative samples in loss function (InfoNCE); Uniformity in constrastive loss; JS-divergence.

item.title: Self-supervised Learning: Generative or Contrastive
item.description:
2021-07-31T14:30:00 -2021-07-31T16:00:00
Liu X, Zhang F, Hou Z, Wang Z, Mian L, Zhang J, et al. Self-supervised Learning: Generative or Contrastive. arXiv [cs.LG]. 2020. Available: http://arxiv.org/abs/2006.08218 We have discussed many topics of generative models. This paper serves as a summary of the current season of the discussions.

item.title: LTD/LTP
item.description:
2021-07-17T14:30:00 -2021-07-17T16:00:00
In this meetup, we will discuss some key ideas related to biological neural network: LTP and LTD.

item.title: Predictive Coding Approximates Backprop along Arbitrary Computation Graphs
item.description:
2021-07-03T14:30:00 -2021-07-03T16:00:00
In this meetup, we will discuss this paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.04182 Why? Feedforward-backprop usually has a loss function that involves all the parameters. Backprop means we need this huge global loss $\mathcal L({w_{ij}})$. However, it is hard to imaging such global loss calculations in our brain. One of the alternatives is predictive coding, which only utilizes local connection information. In this paper (2006.04182), the author proves the equivalence of backprop and predictive coding on arbitary graph.

item.title: Energy-based Models 5
item.description:
2021-06-19T14:30:00 -2021-06-19T16:00:00
In this meetup, we will discuss Restricted Boltzmann Machine (RBM). We will cover the reason for introducing RBM and the training. At the end of the discussion, we will also cover some topics of Deep Boltzmann Machines.

item.title: Energy-based Models 4
item.description:
2021-05-28T14:30:00 -2021-05-28T16:00:00
In this discussion, we will discuss the Pytorch Deep Learning Lectures by LeCun.

item.title: Energy-based Models 3
item.description:
2021-05-15T14:30:00 -2021-05-15T16:00:00
In the past two meetups, we have been discussing EBM from a computer scientist’s perspective. In this discussion, we will discuss chapter XV of Mehta P, Bukov M, Wang C-HH, Day AGRR, Richardson C, Fisher CK, et al. A high-bias, low-variance introduction to Machine Learning for physicists. Phys Rep. 2018;810: 122. doi:10.1016/j.physrep.2019.03.001

item.title: MAF: how is MADE being used
item.description:
2021-03-13T13:30:00 -2021-03-13T16:00:00
We discussed MAF (arXiv:1705.07057v4) last time: The paper did not explain how exactly is MADE being used to update the shift and logscale. We will use the tensorflow implementation of MAF to probe the above question. Here is the link to the relevant documentation: https://www.tensorflow.org/probability/api_docs/python/tfp/bijectors/MaskedAutoregressiveFlow Topics Refer to references. Notes 1310.8499_notes.pdf

item.title: Least Squares, Bootstrap, Maximum Likelihood, and Bayesian
item.description:
2020-12-12T14:30:00 -2020-12-12T16:00:00
Least squares, bootstrap, maximum likelihood, and maximum posterior leads to the same results in many cases.

item.title: Conditional Probability and Bayes
item.description:
2020-11-28T14:30:00 -2020-11-28T16:00:00
The Bayesian view of probability is quite objective and also more general than the frequentist’s view. It doesn’t rely on repeatition of events.
